channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Free Lunch? Yes, Please. Perl job in Vienna.
item.description: One of the largest product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries is on the hunt for a Perl programmer who wants to use their skills to eradicate inflated prices. The successful candidate will relish the chance to join a team that attributes nearly two decades of success to an uncompromising commitment to transparency, objectivity, and quality content.

item.title: We aren’t Mal-teasing—this is the Perl job you’ve been waiting for! Perl in Malta
item.description: We have an international client looking to hire for their Malta office. Looking for Perl developers with a strong background in Modern Perl – you should be comfortable with Moose and PSGI/Plack, and a solid grounding in using Perl’s testing tools. Sun, smiles, scuba … if you haven’t emailed already to jump on this opportunity, then what are you waiting for?

item.title: Grow Your Karma with a Job that Does Good! Perl role in Australia
item.description: Not all jobs are created equal. Sure, most pay the bills, but some do more. They impart a sense of purpose; when you log out at day’s end, it’s with the satisfaction that you are part of something bigger, something more important than yourself. You’ve left the world a little better than you found it, and isn’t that what life is really about?

item.title: Guten Tag, Senior Perl Developers! Perl role in South Germany
item.description: While work for this client is currently 100% remote, their main office is in St. Ingbert, Germany with a satellite office in Munich. With a friendly, sociable crew, a rooftop deck, and all the table soccer and air hockey you can handle. The ideal candidate should be confident using Modern Perl, in particular happy with DBIx::Class and Moose/Moo.

item.title: That’s a Big Sandbox! Perl role in London
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dance, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: German Perl Workshop 2021
item.description: It will take place online between March 24-26 2021. The private ticket will be cheaper (EUR 30). People who register in time and transfer the participation fee, will get exclusive extras.

item.title: Silicon Valley Perl - Regular Expression: Master Manipulator of Text
item.description: Thursday, February 4, 2021; 6:30 PM PST

item.title: Toronto Perl Mongers Online Meeting
item.description: Thursday, January 28, 2021; 7:00 PM EST

item.title: Berlin Perl Mongers
item.description: Wednesday, January 27, 2021; 7:00 PM GMT+1

item.title: Charlotte Perl Mongers - Using the ActiveState Platform
item.description: Wednesday, January 27, 2021; 6:00 PM EST

item.title: Testing in Perl course
item.description: During the last week I made some nice progress recording the Testing in Perl course. So if you are a Perl developer who wants to make sure their code works well, this course can help you learn all the tools you need.

item.title: AoC 2016/19 - Josephus problem
item.description: Never heard of it before, thanks to Flavio, I learnt something new today.

item.title: AoC 2016/15 - Chinese Reminder Theorem - again!
item.description: Thank you Flavio for the refresher, it is always fun to revisit.

item.title: AoC 2016/11 - Part 2 solution
item.description: Setup search using AstarX.pm

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Loop controls: next, last, continue, break
Perl Weekly Challenge 96
item.description: Luis seems to follow the philosophy "Don't re-invent the wheel". I highly recommend the use of CPAN as much as possible.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 96: Reverse Distance
item.description: Roger's blog post is one place where we get to explore more than just Perl solutions. Must Read.

item.title: Perl weekly challenge 096 - Raku
item.description: Joan showing an OO solution to the "Edit Distance" task. Highly Recommended.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 96: Levenshtein distance
item.description: Luca sharing the power of Raku. It reminded me of my days of struggling with Raku.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 96: Reverse Words and Edit Distance (and Decorators in Perl)
item.description: Laurent is teaching us the decorator pattern in Perl this week. You don't want to miss this.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge
item.description: Welcome back Lance with a new shiny website. Cool solutions promoting TDD.

item.title: PWC096 - Edit Distance
item.description: Straight implementation of pseudocode from Wikipedia. No fancy stuff. A pure Perl solution.

item.title: PWC096 - Reverse Words
item.description: Flavio using the power of regex to solve the "Reverse Words" task. Nice and easy to follow.

item.title: Solving Perl Weekly Challenge 096 -- Reverse Words and Edit distance.
item.description: Kang-min exploring Dynamic Programing to deal with the Levenshtein distance. Must Read.

item.title: Going The Distance: Perl Weekly Challenge #96
item.description: Dave presenting Levenshtein Distance solution in a unique way. Highly Recommended.

item.title: The Wagner–Fischer-Price, Backwards
item.description: Colin introducing the Wagner-Fisher algorithm, which is new to me. Need to revisit.

item.title: Reversed Distance with Raku and Perl
item.description: I love it when Arne does both Perl and Raku together. You get to see the similarities. Must Read.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 096
item.description: Adam showing Perl a adaptation of a Haskell implementation deaing with the "Edit Distance" task. An interesting approach.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 96: Edit Distance
item.description: Abigail presenting the mathematical side of the task "Edit Distance". Must Read.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 96: Reverse Words
item.description: Abigail showing off the power of one-liners. Incredible.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 96
item.description: Aaron promoting Raku and encouraging following the official documentation. A short and sweet solutions.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 094
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 096
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Reverse Words" and "Edit Distance" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 097
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks - "Caesar Cipher" and "Binary Substrings". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Regarding the closure of rt.cpan
item.description: Martin picked up a hot topic to discuss. Very useful if you have published module to CPAN.

item.title: Perl Steering Council, meeting #003
item.description: Interesting discussion among the top brass. You don't want to miss it.

item.title: Pull Request Club 2020 Report
item.description: Please checkout Kivanc's annual report for the year 2020. Great work Kivanc, keep it up.

item.title: Roles, h'uh, what are they good for?
item.description: Jesse brought up a good old topic and shares his views with us.

item.title: Mood Lighting
item.description: Toby sharing his Perl skill to automate mood lighting. Worth reading for fun.

item.title: Debugging a web application in Perl
item.description: Mark talking about the most difficult subject. Debugging web app is the most difficult task of any dev.

item.title: Blogs
item.description: Number of posts last week: BPO: 6; DevTo: 7; Perl.com: 0; PerlAcademy: 1; PerlHacks: 0; PerlMaven: 1; Reddit: 18; TPF: 3;

item.title: CPAN uploads
item.description: Last week there were a total of 218 uploads to CPAN of 164 distinct distributions by 95 different authors. Number of distributions with link to VCS: 135. Number of distros with CI: 73. Number of distros with bugtracker: 117.

item.title: A Replacement for PPM - ActiveState's New Perl Ecosystem
item.description: While PPM is gone, the need to install dependencies without requiring a local build environment remains. ActivePerl allowed developers to get up and running quickly by delivering hundreds of popular modules with a single installation. Both use cases are now addressed in ActiveState’s new ecosystem.

item.title: #496 - Statocles vs Hugo
item.description:
Hi there

I think it is unfair to compare the two, but I couldn't stop myself. Let me make this crystal clear, I am talking about two static site builder. Statocles written in Perl and Hugo written in Go.

Why am I even talking about Hugo in the Perl weekly newsletter?

Well, to me it doesn't matter whether it is Perl or any other language. What matters is which one gets the job done quickly. I hear it is matter of personal choice as well. I was first introduced to Hugo when I wrote my first article for Perl.com in 2018. If I am not mistaken, they still use Hugo. I was so impressed with Hugo that I used it to build The Weekly Challenge website. During the peak of my CPAN contributions, I came to know about Statocles. I loved it but never got the opportunity to use it. However I did become one of the contributors to the project. My contribution wasn't ground-breaking, but I feel proud to see my name in the list of contributors. All credit goes to Doug Bell for the coolest tool. For those who don't know him, he leads the team running and managing the CPAN Testers since Barbie took a break.

Last week, I saw a new website perl.kiwi become the talk of the town. It is built using Statocles as the idea behind the website is to promote Perl. I am going to keep an eye out for fun stuff related to Perl. I loved the domain name. Congratulations Lance Wicks.

Talking about promoting Perl, Sawyer shared the details of the 3rd Perl Steering Council meeting. There was another big annoucement by Sawyer with regard to the release date of Perl v5.34. We should all be thankful to the PSC members for their time and efforts.

Last time I forgot to mention about the Pull Request Club 2020 Report by Kivanc Yazan. Kudos to Kivanc for running the club for 2 years now. Keep it up. You are doing a great service to the Perl community.

Last but not the least, please don't forget to watch the weekly show, "Perl Town Hall" by Will Braswell on Facebook. It doesn't suit my timezone but I do watch it the recordings later.

Enjoy the rest of the newsletter
